Award.AwardTitle: US-Spain Planning Visit: Plastic Optical Fiber (POF) Systems for Avionics Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Improved communication capabilities in airplanes are a continuing goal in the avionics field. Plastic Optical Fibers (POF) have been used extensively in automobiles, and their characteristics in enduring harsh environments make them particularly attractive for use in avionics. Improvements in this area could lead to more efficient systems in airplanes, with reduced energy costs given their light weight. This project will examine ways to optimize the characteristics of POF for application in airplane systems, by collaborating with researchers at the University of Zaragoza in Spain, who are experts in computer modeling of these systems.

The findings from this project may lead to improved communication systems in airplanes, decreased energy costs and increased efficiency. Further, the development of applications to avionics may provide insight for applications in other systems with similarly wide distribution, such as telecommunications networks. In addition, collaborating with foreign researchers at the host institution will provide the graduate student with access to expertise not available at the home institution. This type of experience provides US students with the capacity to participate in a globally competitive workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our project has achived all its intended outcomes and more, as follows:

Our PhD student was able to interact with an international research group whose members are world-leaders in the study of Plastic Optical Fiber. She was able to work in their laboratory in Spain, get exposed to world-class research and not only start her PhD thesis in a positive way, as we were anticipating at the beginning of the award, but to advance well into the research to the point where she is now very close to defending her work. In the process, she was able to obtain a great deal of measurements for different kinds of fibers, develop an improved model for POF and lay the groundwork for a new experiment (the first of its kind) that will demo a real POF avionics system complete with realistic number of connectors and advanced modulation formats for high bit rate transmission. Throughout the process, she also got exposed to the international research environment, presented her work at a leading international conference and most importantly, she was able to inspire young women engineers and a general population of undergraduates who are traditionally under-exposed to advanced research at the City University of New York. 

On the latter, our PhD student has been able to effectively present her work, inspire and at the same time mentor a number of  female engineering students that attended a Women In Science and Engineering Workshop that was organized at CSI last year. She spent about 45 minutes presenting her work, talking to the students and explaining the whole experience. On another instance, this past summer, she spend about 1 hour with undergraduate upper-classment at CSI delving in more detail to her research results and answering questions. She has also spent time during the duration of the grant award talking to prospective MS and PhD students both at the College of Staten Island (CSI) as well as the City College of New York (CCNY), both senior colleges of The City University of NY (CUNY), and encouraging them to continue to work on higher level of research.

All along, our entire work based on the support by this grant has enabled us to continue attracting the interest of a leading avionics company who constantly provides us with state-of-the-art experimental components and so we are now ready to construct our intended avionics testbed.
